00051 /*
00052  * EXO(-skeletal) definitions:
00053  *
00054  *   The EXO format is used to store and retrieve data structures from text
00055  *   files.  The following BNF definition defines the contents of an EXO file:
00056  *
00057  *      <exo_file>      := <exo_term>
00058  *
00059  *      <exo_term>      := <exo_term_list>
00060  *                         | INTEGER
00061  *                         | FLOAT
00062  *                         | CHAR
00063  *                         | STRING
00064  *
00065  *      <exo_term_list> := (<exo_term_list> ',' <exo_term>)
00066  *                         | <exo_term>
00067  */
00068 
00069 #ifndef EXO_H
00070 #define EXO_H
00071 
00072 #ifdef __cplusplus
00073 extern "C" {
00074 #endif
00075 
00076 #include "../host.h"
00077 #include "../misc.h"
00078 #include "../machine.h"
00079 
00080 /* EXO file format versions */
00081 #define EXO_FMT_MAJOR           1
00082 #define EXO_FMT_MINOR           0
00083 
00084 /* EXO term classes, keep this in sync with EXO_CLASS_STR */
00085 enum exo_class_t {
00086   ec_integer,                   /* EXO int value */
00087   ec_address,                   /* EXO address value */
00088   ec_float,                     /* EXO FP value */
00089   ec_char,                      /* EXO character value */
00090   ec_string,                    /* EXO string value */
00091   ec_list,                      /* EXO list */
00092   ec_array,                     /* EXO array */
00093   ec_token,                     /* EXO token value */
00094   ec_blob,                      /* EXO blob (Binary Large OBject) */
00095   ec_null,                      /* used internally */
00096   ec_NUM
00097 };
00098 
00099 /* EXO term classes print strings */
00100 extern char *exo_class_str[ec_NUM];
00101 
00102 /* EXO token table entry */
00103 struct exo_token_t {
00104   struct exo_token_t *next;     /* next element in a hash buck chain */
00105   char *str;                    /* token string */
00106   int token;                    /* token value */
00107 };
00108 
00109 struct exo_term_t {
00110   struct exo_term_t *next;      /* next element, when in a list */
00111   enum exo_class_t ec;          /* term node class */
00112   union {
00113     struct as_integer_t {
00114       exo_integer_t val;                /* integer value */
00115     } as_integer;
00116     struct as_address_t {
00117 #if defined(sparc) && (defined(TARGET_ARM) || defined(TARGET_PISA))
00118       word_t _dummy;
00119 #endif
00120       exo_address_t val;                /* address value */
00121     } as_address;
00122     struct as_float_t {
00123       exo_float_t val;                  /* floating point value */
00124     } as_float;
00125     struct as_char_t {
00126       char val;                         /* character value */
00127     } as_char;
00128     struct as_string_t {
00129       unsigned char *str;               /* string value */
00130     } as_string;
00131     struct as_list_t {
00132       struct exo_term_t *head;          /* list head pointer */
00133     } as_list;
00134     struct as_array_t {
00135       int size;                         /* size of the array */
00136       struct exo_term_t **array;        /* list head pointer */
00137     } as_array;
00138     struct as_token_t {
00139       struct exo_token_t *ent;          /* token table entry */
00140     } as_token;
00141     struct as_blob_t {
00142       int size;                         /* byte size of object */
00143       unsigned char *data;              /* pointer to blob data */
00144     } as_blob;
00145   } variant;
00146 };
00147 /* short-cut accessors */
00148 #define as_integer      variant.as_integer
00149 #define as_address      variant.as_address
00150 #define as_float        variant.as_float
00151 #define as_char         variant.as_char
00152 #define as_string       variant.as_string
00153 #define as_list         variant.as_list
00154 #define as_array        variant.as_array
00155 #define as_token        variant.as_token
00156 #define as_blob         variant.as_blob
00157 
00158 /* EXO array accessor, may be used as an L-value or R-value */
00159 /* EXO array accessor, may be used as an L-value or R-value */
00160 #define EXO_ARR(E,N)                                                    \
00161   ((E)->ec != ec_array                                                  \
00162    ? (fatal("not an array"), *(struct exo_term_t **)(NULL))             \
00163    : ((N) >= (E)->as_array.size                                         \
00164       ? (fatal("array bounds error"), *(struct exo_term_t **)(NULL))    \
00165       : (E)->as_array.array[(N)]))
00166 #define SET_EXO_ARR(E,N,V)                                              \
00167   ((E)->ec != ec_array                                                  \
00168    ? (void)fatal("not an array")                                        \
00169    : ((N) >= (E)->as_array.size                                         \
00170       ? (void)fatal("array bounds error")                               \
00171       : (void)((E)->as_array.array[(N)] = (V))))
00172 
00173 /* intern token TOKEN_STR */
00174 struct exo_token_t *
00175 exo_intern(char *token_str);            /* string to intern */
00176 
00177 /* intern token TOKEN_STR as value TOKEN */
00178 struct exo_token_t *
00179 exo_intern_as(char *token_str,          /* string to intern */
00180               int token);               /* internment value */
00181 
00182 /*
00183  * create a new EXO term, usage:
00184  *
00185  *      exo_new(ec_integer, (exo_integer_t)<int>);
00186  *      exo_new(ec_address, (exo_address_t)<int>);
00187  *      exo_new(ec_float, (exo_float_t)<float>);
00188  *      exo_new(ec_char, (int)<char>);
00189  *      exo_new(ec_string, "<string>");
00190  *      exo_new(ec_list, <list_ent>..., NULL);
00191  *      exo_new(ec_array, <size>, <array_ent>..., NULL);
00192  *      exo_new(ec_token, "<token>");
00193  *      exo_new(ec_blob, <size>, <data_ptr>);
00194  */
00195 struct exo_term_t *
00196 exo_new(enum exo_class_t ec, ...);
00197 
00198 /* release an EXO term */
00199 void
00200 exo_delete(struct exo_term_t *exo);
00201 
00202 /* chain two EXO lists together, FORE is attached on the end of AFT */
00203 struct exo_term_t *
00204 exo_chain(struct exo_term_t *fore, struct exo_term_t *aft);
00205 
00206 /* copy an EXO node */
00207 struct exo_term_t *
00208 exo_copy(struct exo_term_t *exo);
00209 
00210 /* deep copy an EXO structure */
00211 struct exo_term_t *
00212 exo_deepcopy(struct exo_term_t *exo);
00213 
00214 /* print an EXO term */
00215 void
00216 exo_print(struct exo_term_t *exo, FILE *stream);
00217 
00218 /* read one EXO term from STREAM */
00219 struct exo_term_t *
00220 exo_read(FILE *stream);
00221 
00222 /* check the format of an EXO component, returns non-zero if EXO matches,
00223    elements expected are specified by FMT as follows:
00224 
00225         i  - integer            a  - address
00226         f  - float              c  - character
00227         s  - string             () - list
00228         [] - array              t  - token
00229         b  - blob
00230 
00231    Node elements are written to trailing arguments which must be of type
00232    specified in the format type string FMT. (See eio.c for example usage.)
00233 
00234    NOTE1: lists () and arrays [] do NOT bind to a pointer argument.
00235    NOTE2: blobs 'b' bind to two arguments, the first is an 'int *' which
00236      specifies the size of the blob, and the second is an 'unsigned char **'
00237      which is updated with a pointer to the binary block (likely READ ONLY!).
00238 */
00239 int exo_parse(struct exo_term_t *exo, char *fmt, ...);
00240 
00241 /* just like exo_parse, but no argument variable binding, only checks */
00242 int exo_check(struct exo_term_t *exo, char *fmt);
00243 
00244 
00245 /* lexor components */
00246 enum lex_t {
00247   lex_integer = 256,
00248   lex_address,
00249   lex_float,
00250   lex_char,
00251   lex_string,
00252   lex_token,
00253   lex_byte,
00254   lex_eof
00255 };
00256 
00257 #ifdef __cplusplus
00258 }
